title: WE'RE BACK TO THE PED NOT SPENDING ENOUGH ON SPECIAL EDUCATION AND PUTTING FEDERAL $$ AT RISK.

A while back, in fact several years ago, we reported extensively on a problem with the Public Education Department and funding for special education.The federal government said that New Mexico had not maintained level funding for special ed, and was at risk of losing federal aid.Now. The state auditor says that the state failed to spend $110 million in federal funds on the special education students between July 2009 and June 2013.That shortfall puts the state at risk of losing millions from the feds.Attorney General Hector Balderas, who was state auditor, ordered the special audit and told the Legislature in 2014 the state could lose $60 million.The audit also reported the PED knew of the problem, but didn’t tell lawmakers.Now Auditor Tim Keller says “This report highlights serious shortcomings in our state’s ability to serve special education students, who are some of the most vulnerable participants in our education system and deserve better.”The Santa Fe New Mexican did a story about the issue and has requested a response from the PED.The Legislative Education Study Committee first raised this issue in 2013, and since then the department has been involved in lawsuits and filings with the U.S. Department of Education over the way the feds calculate special education funding.The state also requested a waiver from the funding requirements during the recession.The Department of Ed so far hasn’t bought the state’s argument, but then neither did a hearings judge who wrote the state that he’s “unpersuaded” by the state’s argument they have the right to reduce funding for special education if they wish.  The judge says the state has to meet a base level of funding and can only increase it.The federal money the state could lose is important.  It pays for such things as counseling, aides, diagnostics and speech and language help.  That is all included in the Individualized Education Programs for many of the nearly 47,000 special education students.The auditor says the state failed to spend $47 million in 2010, $30 million in 2012 and $35 million in 2011.While the state says they have the right to do what they wish in the funding of special education services, if they don’t toe the federal line, they lose millions and will end up having to spend that and more on the services now paid by Washington.The Legislature will certainly have something to say about the latest round fired by Democrat Tim Keller, the State Auditor.Since he’s been in office, he has gone after agencies and their leaders more aggressively than ever before.Some on the GOP side say it is a political witch hunt that he’s trying to take down the Republican Party.Keller, of course, denies that and says he’s just doing his job.If you have any questions, comments or suggestions, please let me know at mark.bentley76@gmail.com.Thanks for reading!© All rights reserved
